title.narrative: Strategic advice to the Vietnamese Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development on river training and management in the Mekong Delta

description.narrative: Both Vietnam and the Netherlands are facing vital challenges for managing the deltas of the Mekong and the Rhine River, respectively. Because of many commonalities in both deltas a long-term co-operation was started long ago in the field of river and coastal management. In this framework the Dutch government has enabled a project to support the Vietnamese government with technical and strategic advice on the management of scour and bank erosion in the Mekong Delta. This assignment was financed through the Partners for Water Program, executed by the Netherlands Enterprise Agency (RVO), part of the Netherlands Ministry of Economic Affairs and Climate. Presently in the Vietnamese Mekong Delta (VMD) there are more than 600 riverbank erosion sites with a total length of 590 km. In many areas, erosion has directly threatened people's lives and property and many households must be relocated due to destruction of their houses through bank collapse. Also, roads and other infrastructure damages have been reported frequently. The scale and consequences of river erosion shows the urgency of an integral plan for bank protection.The report has been drafted as part of the Netherlands/Vietnam cooperation on delta challenges and focuses on the problem of riverbank erosion and its solutions. It shares state-of-the-arts views, methods and constructive ideas to deal with these challenges, by presenting a systemic perspective as well as inspiring experiences from international practice.The report reflects the changes in river-engineering towards more flexible adaptive strategies that ‘work with nature’ rather than ‘resist forces of nature’. The scale of stresses in the Vietnam Mekong Delta, such as massive sand mining, sea-level rise, rapid subsidence, dam impacts and social and economic drivers, require a systematic program for fighting bank erosion. The experts believe that the erosion of riverbanks in the VMD can be managed and controlled in the future by the river managers if they enable this transition in their practice by using a blend of river training, with hard infrastructure, and river engineering, with sediment management (dredging, nourishment) and Building with Nature.
